name: 4-bromo-3-(trifluoromethyl)benzenesulfonamide
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The following functional group contributions can be considered: the bromine substituent increases the melting point due to its significant mass and polarizability, estimated at about +80°C. The trifluoromethyl group, being highly electronegative and introducing strong dipole-dipole interactions, also raises the melting point, estimated at +50°C. Finally, the benzenesulfonamide moiety is a large polar group capable of strong intermolecular interactions, including hydrogen bonding, which would significantly raise the melting point, estimated at +100°C.

name: 4-bromo-3-(trifluoromethyl)benzenesulfonamide
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 °C. A bromine atom, being a large, electron-withdrawing group, typically raises the melting point significantly due to increased molecular weight and stronger intermolecular interactions (+60 °C). The trifluoromethyl group is highly electronegative and also increases the melting point due to the polar nature of the C–F bonds and the additional fluoro substituents' influence on the solid-state lattice (+40 °C). Lastly, the sulfonamide group adds substantial polar character and ability to form hydrogen bonds, leading to a strong increase in the melting point (+80 °C). The combined effect of these groups on benzene is expected to give a substantial cumulative increase in the melting point.
Prediction: The melting point of 4-bromo-3-(trifluoromethyl)benzenesulfonamide is expected to be 5.5 (benzene base) + 60 (bromo group) + 40 (trifluoromethyl group) + 80 (sulfonamide group) = 185.5 °C
